column4: Ok, here is an interesting one.  How do when I set the permission for a folder, such as who has write ability and such, ensure that it replecates all they way down to every file within that folder?
Ok, here is an interesting one.  How do when I set the permission for a folder, such as who has write ability and such, ensure that it replecates all they way down to every file within that folder?
could have also typed man chmod.. its right there, first page
first page of what?
man chmod
should say only page
thanks :)
ok, I am not understanding this. I have typed: chmod -R /home/titan/WoW   to change it so I have rights to right to everything in that folder but it gives me a 'to few arguments' error.
you forgot the permissions. chmod 755 -R /home/titan/WoW
except 755 isn't what you want. thats just an example
no.. I did not forget it, I just did not know about it =P I am pretty new to linux.
woops. typos. chmod -R 755 /some/path
ahh. well you get it
ummm... so how do I tell what numbers I type instead of 775, I don't understand those mans. :(
hrm. thats hard to . that man chmod explains it, but reading that stuff is nearly impossible.
ya, I do not understand it, oh well I will go back and look again. THanks.
the first digit is the owners permissions. the second the groups, the third is everyone else. so 755 is owner has permission of 7, group of 5 and everyone else 5
so if I say chmod 777 -R /path   then that should set it so everyone has writes to read, write and execute?
you got it
awsome :) Thanks alot!
not a good idea. 755 is already a lot of access
oh ok, I think I am owner anyhow so  Ishould be fine to do 755
it worked, thanks alot for your help. I'm off, got some martial arts to do, thanks again.
np.
